name: Limits
description: The foundation of calculus, defining how a function behaves as its input approaches a specific value. Limits formalize the concept of approaching a value and are essential for defining derivatives and integrals.
key_formulas: One-sided limits: lim(x→a⁺) f(x) and lim(x→a⁻) f(x)
misconceptions: A limit is not a substitution (although it sometimes coincides)
Limits at discontinuities can still exist
Limits can exist even when the function is not defined at that point
A function can approach different values from different directions (one-sided limits)

name: Derivatives
description: The rate of change of a function with respect to its variable. Derivatives measure how a function changes at any given point and are used to find slopes of curves, rates of change, and optimization.
misconceptions: Derivatives don't measure absolute change, but rate of change
A derivative of zero doesn't always indicate a minimum or maximum
The second derivative test has conditions for conclusive results
Differentiability implies continuity, but not vice versa

name: Integrals
description: The accumulation of quantities, such as areas under curves, volumes, or any quantity that accumulates over a range of values. Integrals are the inverse operation of differentiation and include both definite and indefinite forms.
key_formulas: Indefinite integral: ∫f(x)dx = F(x) + C where F'(x) = f(x)
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus: d/dx[∫ₐˣf(t)dt] = f(x)
Integration by substitution: ∫f(g(x))g'(x)dx = ∫f(u)du where u = g(x)
misconceptions: Integration is not always the reverse of differentiation in a straightforward way
Not all functions have elementary antiderivatives
Improper integrals can converge even with discontinuities
Integration by parts requires careful choice of u and v

name: Multivariate Calculus
description: The extension of calculus to functions of multiple variables. It includes partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus, dealing with rates of change and accumulation in multiple dimensions.
misconceptions: Critical points in multivariable functions require testing beyond derivatives being zero
Mixed partial derivatives are not always equal (requires continuous second derivatives)
Order of integration can affect difficulty but not the result in multiple integrals
Conservative vector fields have specific properties not shared by all fields

name: Vectors and Vector Spaces
description: Mathematical objects with magnitude and direction, and the spaces they occupy. Vectors are the foundation of linear algebra and are used to represent physical quantities, data points, and abstract mathematical concepts.
key_formulas: Dot product: u·v = u₁v₁ + u₂v₂ + ... + uₙvₙ
misconceptions: Vectors are not just lists of numbers but elements of a vector space
The dot product is not a vector but a scalar
The cross product is only defined in 3D and 7D spaces
Not all vector operations are commutative

name: Matrices and Matrix Operations
description: Rectangular arrays of numbers or symbols arranged in rows and columns, used to represent linear transformations, solve systems of equations, and organize data in a structured format.
misconceptions: Matrix multiplication is not commutative (AB ≠ BA in general)
Not all matrices have inverses (singular matrices)
Matrix operations have specific dimension requirements
The determinant being zero has important implications

name: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
description: Special scalars and vectors associated with a square matrix that remain in the same direction or reverse direction when that linear transformation is applied. These are fundamental concepts for understanding how matrices act on vector spaces.
key_formulas: Eigendecomposition: A = PDP⁻¹ (when A has n linearly independent eigenvectors)
Spectral theorem (for symmetric matrices): A = QΛQᵀ
Diagonalization condition: A is diagonalizable if and only if it has n linearly independent eigenvectors
misconceptions: Not all matrices have real eigenvalues (need to consider complex ones)
Not all matrices are diagonalizable
Eigenvectors corresponding to different eigenvalues are linearly independent
The number of linearly independent eigenvectors for an eigenvalue may be less than its multiplicity

name: Linear Algebra Applications
description: The practical use of linear algebra concepts in various fields, including data science, computer science, engineering, physics, and economics. This covers how theoretical concepts translate to real-world problem-solving.
misconceptions: Linear algebra is not just for abstract mathematics but has numerous practical applications
Many real-world processes are approximated as linear when they are actually nonlinear
The choice of basis can significantly affect the complexity of problem-solving
Many machine learning algorithms are fundamentally linear algebra operations

name: Descriptive Statistics
description: Methods for summarizing and describing the main features of a dataset, without making inferences or predictions. This includes measures of central tendency, dispersion, and data visualization techniques.
key_formulas: Median: middle value when data is ordered
Percentiles: value below which P% of observations fall
misconceptions: Mean, median, and mode can be very different in skewed distributions
Standard deviation is not a complete description of data spread
Descriptive statistics can be misleading without proper visualization
Sample statistics are not the same as population parameters

name: Probability and Distributions
description: The study of randomness and uncertainty, focusing on the likelihood of events and the mathematical distributions that model random phenomena. This forms the foundation for statistical inference and prediction.
key_formulas: Probability: P(A) = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of possible outcomes
Conditional probability: P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B)
applications: Risk assessment in finance and insurance
misconceptions: Correlation does not imply causation
The gambler's fallacy (past outcomes affecting future probability)
Confusing independence and mutual exclusivity
Assuming all distributions are normal
Misunderstanding conditional probability

name: Inferential Statistics
description: Methods for making inferences, predictions, and generalizations about a population based on a sample. This includes hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and regression analysis.
key_formulas: Standard error of the mean: SE = σ/√n
p-value: probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as the observed results
Regression equation: y = β₀ + β₁x + ε
R-squared: proportion of variance explained by the model
misconceptions: Statistical significance doesn't necessarily imply practical significance
Confidence intervals don't show the probability of containing the parameter
p-values don't measure the probability that the null hypothesis is true
Multiple testing increases the chance of false positives
Sample size affects both precision and power of tests

name: Applied Data Analysis
description: Practical application of statistical methods to real-world data, including data cleaning, exploratory analysis, modeling, and interpretation. This bridges pure statistics with domain-specific insights.
key_formulas: Principal components: eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix
Cross-validation error: average error across k test subsets
misconceptions: Big data doesn't eliminate the need for careful statistical analysis
Model complexity doesn't always improve predictive performance
Domain knowledge is crucial for proper interpretation
Observational data has limitations for causal inference
Statistical software output requires proper understanding for interpretation
